values.description:
@nkoenig , I changed the HTML file in order to test better connections, disconnections and subscriptions.

Now, we subscribe to the topic by clicking the button. It’s not subscribed by default.

The ``lws_issue_raw: Assertion `0' failed`` error seems to happen when we subscribe to a topic multiple times \(which we can do by clicking the subscribe many times\). It seems like the Server never “releases” these subscriptions?

Something interesting to check:

You can open multiple html files and subscribe in each. If the server doesn’t crashes, you can see the messages on the first one you subscribed to. The second client doesn’t receive the messages until we disconnect the first client. Here’s a GIF of it.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/ngEao5e/images/1361775545-websocketConnections.gif)
I hope this helps for better debugging
values.title: HTML file update

summary.raw:
@nkoenig , I changed the HTML file in order to test better connections, disconnections and subscriptions.

Now, we subscribe to the topic by clicking the button. It’s not subscribed by default.

The ``lws_issue_raw: Assertion `0' failed`` error seems to happen when we subscribe to a topic multiple times \(which we can do by clicking the subscribe many times\). It seems like the Server never “releases” these subscriptions?

Something interesting to check:

You can open multiple html files and subscribe in each. If the server doesn’t crashes, you can see the messages on the first one you subscribed to. The second client doesn’t receive the messages until we disconnect the first client. Here’s a GIF of it.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/ngEao5e/images/1361775545-websocketConnections.gif)
I hope this helps for better debugging
summary.html:
@nkoenig , I changed the HTML file in order to test better connections, disconnections and subscriptions.

Now, we subscribe to the topic by clicking the button. It’s not subscribed by default.

The lws_issue_raw: Assertion `0' failed error seems to happen when we subscribe to a topic multiple times (which we can do by clicking the subscribe many times). It seems like the Server never “releases” these subscriptions?

Something interesting to check:

You can open multiple html files and subscribe in each. If the server doesn’t crashes, you can see the messages on the first one you subscribed to. The second client doesn’t receive the messages until we disconnect the first client. Here’s a GIF of it.

I hope this helps for better debugging

values.description:
Bug: The positional argument is not handled properly. Without this PR, the following doesn't work:

```
ign launch <filename> -v 4
```

Bug 2: The websocket plugin contained version information in the name. This has been removed.
values.title: Fix positional argument

summary.raw:
Bug: The positional argument is not handled properly. Without this PR, the following doesn't work:

```
ign launch <filename> -v 4
```

Bug 2: The websocket plugin contained version information in the name. This has been removed.
summary.html:
Bug: The positional argument is not handled properly. Without this PR, the following doesn't work:

ign launch <filename> -v 4

Bug 2: The websocket plugin contained version information in the name. This has been removed.

values.description:
This PR fixes three problems:

1. `this->app->AddPluginPath(IGN_GAZEBO_GUI_PLUGIN_INSTALL_DIR);` is required to find gazebo gui plugins.

2. The `gazebo_gui` plugin needs to use the `GuiRunner`

3. Pressing `ctrl-c` rapidly in a row would cause a mutex deadlock. See changes made to `Manager.cc`.
values.title: Fix gazebo gui to use GuiRunner

summary.raw:
This PR fixes three problems:

1. `this->app->AddPluginPath(IGN_GAZEBO_GUI_PLUGIN_INSTALL_DIR);` is required to find gazebo gui plugins.

2. The `gazebo_gui` plugin needs to use the `GuiRunner`

3. Pressing `ctrl-c` rapidly in a row would cause a mutex deadlock. See changes made to `Manager.cc`.
summary.html:
This PR fixes three problems:

  1. this->app->AddPluginPath(IGN_GAZEBO_GUI_PLUGIN_INSTALL_DIR); is required to find gazebo gui plugins.

  2. The gazebo_gui plugin needs to use the GuiRunner

  3. Pressing ctrl-c rapidly in a row would cause a mutex deadlock. See changes made to Manager.cc.

values.description:
This PR captures command line arguments of the form <name>:=<value>. Variables are created with the corresponding name and value. These variables are passed to ERB.

We need this for Cloudsim, which needs to launch simulation with different options than a local instance. Ideally, we won't have two sets of launch files: one for cloudsim and one for local execution.

See the `gazebo_plugins.ign` file for usage information.
values.title: [Blueprint] Passing args to launch on the command line

summary.raw:
This PR captures command line arguments of the form <name>:=<value>. Variables are created with the corresponding name and value. These variables are passed to ERB.

We need this for Cloudsim, which needs to launch simulation with different options than a local instance. Ideally, we won't have two sets of launch files: one for cloudsim and one for local execution.

See the `gazebo_plugins.ign` file for usage information.
summary.html:
This PR captures command line arguments of the form <name>:=<value>. Variables are created with the corresponding name and value. These variables are passed to ERB.

We need this for Cloudsim, which needs to launch simulation with different options than a local instance. Ideally, we won't have two sets of launch files: one for cloudsim and one for local execution.

See the gazebo_plugins.ign file for usage information.

values.description:
This allows copying the values of an env var to another like this:

~~~
  <env>
    <name>IGN_GAZEBO_SYSTEM_PLUGIN_PATH</name>
    <value>$LD_LIBRARY_PATH</value>
  </env>
~~~

Which is equivalent to doing:

`export IGN_GAZEBO_SYSTEM_PLUGIN_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH`
values.title: Copy env var value

summary.raw:
This allows copying the values of an env var to another like this:

~~~
  <env>
    <name>IGN_GAZEBO_SYSTEM_PLUGIN_PATH</name>
    <value>$LD_LIBRARY_PATH</value>
  </env>
~~~

Which is equivalent to doing:

`export IGN_GAZEBO_SYSTEM_PLUGIN_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH`
summary.html:
This allows copying the values of an env var to another like this:

  <env>
    <name>IGN_GAZEBO_SYSTEM_PLUGIN_PATH</name>
    <value>$LD_LIBRARY_PATH</value>
  </env>

Which is equivalent to doing:

export IGN_GAZEBO_SYSTEM_PLUGIN_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH

values.description:
This adds backward \([https://github.com/bombela/backward-cpp](https://github.com/bombela/backward-cpp)\) to help sanitize some of the backtraces from faults in the plugins.

It also adds some additional debugging output to introspect state when a shutdown is occurring.

Backward needs `binutils-dev` installed `apt-get install binutils-dev`

This is WIP, because some of this debug output is unnecessary long-term.
values.title: [WIP] Use backward to sanitize backtraces

summary.raw:
This adds backward \([https://github.com/bombela/backward-cpp](https://github.com/bombela/backward-cpp)\) to help sanitize some of the backtraces from faults in the plugins.

It also adds some additional debugging output to introspect state when a shutdown is occurring.

Backward needs `binutils-dev` installed `apt-get install binutils-dev`

This is WIP, because some of this debug output is unnecessary long-term.
summary.html:
This adds backward (https://github.com/bombela/backward-cpp) to help sanitize some of the backtraces from faults in the plugins.

It also adds some additional debugging output to introspect state when a shutdown is occurring.

Backward needs binutils-dev installed apt-get install binutils-dev

This is WIP, because some of this debug output is unnecessary long-term.

values.reason: Reopening against latest with less debug output.

values.description:
There were two potential bugs in the way that the SIGCHLD handler was written previously. In one case, the mutex would be locked when the signal was handled, and the handler could not get a lock. In other cases, some of the operations we were doing in the handler were not strictly safe.

As a fix, I have introduced a queue that is populated by the handler and consumed via a worker thread. These use a semaphore to signal \(which is safe\).

This addresses #6 and likely resolves remaining issues in osrf/subt#95

‌

Test with the launch file from #6.  Without this fix, the launch process will lock and not respond correctly to ctrl-c.  With the fix, startup and shutdown should proceed normally.
values.title: Eliminate potential deadlock from SIGCHLD signal handler

summary.raw:
There were two potential bugs in the way that the SIGCHLD handler was written previously. In one case, the mutex would be locked when the signal was handled, and the handler could not get a lock. In other cases, some of the operations we were doing in the handler were not strictly safe.

As a fix, I have introduced a queue that is populated by the handler and consumed via a worker thread. These use a semaphore to signal \(which is safe\).

This addresses #6 and likely resolves remaining issues in osrf/subt#95

‌

Test with the launch file from #6.  Without this fix, the launch process will lock and not respond correctly to ctrl-c.  With the fix, startup and shutdown should proceed normally.
summary.html:
There were two potential bugs in the way that the SIGCHLD handler was written previously. In one case, the mutex would be locked when the signal was handled, and the handler could not get a lock. In other cases, some of the operations we were doing in the handler were not strictly safe.

As a fix, I have introduced a queue that is populated by the handler and consumed via a worker thread. These use a semaphore to signal (which is safe).

This addresses #6 and likely resolves remaining issues in osrf/subt#95

‌

Test with the launch file from #6. Without this fix, the launch process will lock and not respond correctly to ctrl-c. With the fix, startup and shutdown should proceed normally.

Needs [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/397/blueprint-logging-meshes-and-materials/diff#chg-include/ignition/gazebo/ServerConfig.hh) `ign-gazebo` PR.

`ign launch -v 4 gazebo_plugins.ign world:=diff_drive.sdf`

For logging resources, test with:

`ign launch -v 4 gazebo_plugins.ign worldName:=quadcopter`

values.description:
* Window title -> 1

* Close branch window_title_1

* Parse <seed> elements within the GazeboServer plugin.

* Using QueryUnsignedText().

* Copy env var value

* Close branch copy_env

* Use ignition Gazebo 2 from debs in pipelines.

* Changelog and 1.2.0

* Close branch seed

* Added tag ignition-launch_1.2.0 for changeset 53f61e939155

* Eliminate potential deadlock from SIGCHLD signal handler

    There were two potential bugs in the way that the SIGCHLD handler was written
    previously. In one case, the mutex would be locked when the signal was handled,
    and the handler could not get a lock. In other cases, some of the operations
    we were doing in the handler were not strictly safe.

    As a fix, I have introduced a queue that is populated by the handler and
    consumed via a worker thread. These use a semaphore to signal (which is safe).

* Actually start the worker thread

* Switch to named semaphores for macOS

* Check if master before closing/unlinking semaphore

* Close branch sigchld_deadlock_fix

* 1.2.1

* Added tag ignition-launch_1.2.1 for changeset 5b7756bc5075

* Set sane and non-conflicting remotery ports.

* Expose ign-gazebo update rate

* Close branch rmt_ports

* Manager.cc: fix codecheck

* Close branch update_rate

* Window title

* Support console logging

* Close branch window_icon

* Close branch update_logging

* 1.2.2

* Added tag ignition-launch_1.2.2 for changeset 14c099f7c8f0

* Add backward support to ign-launch to capture backtraces.

* Fix codecheck

* Add known bad plugin as an integration test

* Codecheck

* Added check for library existance

* Use the upstream config file for discovery

* add import path

* changelog

* Remove matching regex.

* Close branch qml_import_path

* Skip integration test in coverage

* Bump to 1.2.3

* Close branch bump_1.2.3

* Added tag ignition-launch_1.2.3 for changeset 34a2b0921f24

* Fix test scoping, re-enable in coverage

* Put the runConfig in separate method.

* Update readme contents

* FAIL -> EXIT

* Suppress cppcheck from vendor in jenkins as well

* Drop the check because it varies by platform

* Remove unnecessary message

* Close branch add_backward

* Review updates

* Close branch update_readme

• Window title -> 1

  • Parse <seed> elements within the GazeboServer plugin.

  • Changelog and 1.2.0

  • Added tag ignition-launch_1.2.0 for changeset 53f61e939155

  • Eliminate potential deadlock from SIGCHLD signal handler

    There were two potential bugs in the way that the SIGCHLD handler was written previously. In one case, the mutex would be locked when the signal was handled, and the handler could not get a lock. In other cases, some of the operations we were doing in the handler were not strictly safe.

    As a fix, I have introduced a queue that is populated by the handler and consumed via a worker thread. These use a semaphore to signal (which is safe).

  • Actually start the worker thread
